body:
Hello @h-vetinari! Thanks for submitting the PR.

 - There are no PEP8 issues in the file [`pandas/io/excel.py`](https://github.com/h-vetinari/pandas/blob/a4858ae984a5b1c76508b7b708854b10c1418b81/pandas/io/excel.py) !

 - There are no PEP8 issues in the file [`pandas/io/parquet.py`](https://github.com/h-vetinari/pandas/blob/a4858ae984a5b1c76508b7b708854b10c1418b81/pandas/io/parquet.py) !

 - There are no PEP8 issues in the file [`pandas/tests/io/conftest.py`](https://github.com/h-vetinari/pandas/blob/a4858ae984a5b1c76508b7b708854b10c1418b81/pandas/tests/io/conftest.py) !

 - There are no PEP8 issues in the file [`pandas/tests/io/json/test_compression.py`](https://github.com/h-vetinari/pandas/blob/a4858ae984a5b1c76508b7b708854b10c1418b81/pandas/tests/io/json/test_compression.py) !

 - There are no PEP8 issues in the file [`pandas/tests/io/test_excel.py`](https://github.com/h-vetinari/pandas/blob/a4858ae984a5b1c76508b7b708854b10c1418b81/pandas/tests/io/test_excel.py) !

 - There are no PEP8 issues in the file [`pandas/tests/io/test_s3.py`](https://github.com/h-vetinari/pandas/blob/a4858ae984a5b1c76508b7b708854b10c1418b81/pandas/tests/io/test_s3.py) !

> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23731?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [7b0fa8e...b532696](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23731?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

After an absurd amount of time trying to hunt down these warnings, I think I found the culprit/solution boto/botocore#1464.

The warning is from a vendored requests/urrlib3 in botocore, which didn't close a session/socket. Unfortunately, there are no means that I found (and I tried a lot) that can catch this warning. Failed attempts include:
* `warnings.catch_warnings()` with `simplefilter` or `filterwarning`
* `capsys`/`capfd`/`capsysbinary`/`capsysfd` fixtures from pytest
* `tm.capture_stderr` and `tm.capture_stdout`
* setting `os.environ["PYTHONWARNINGS"]`
* passing `-W ignore::ResourceWarning` to the pytest call

The *only* thing that had an effect (but still didn't work) was `-W error::ResourceWarning`:
```
(pandas-dev) C:\[...]\pddev>pytest pandas/tests/io/test_parquet.py -W error::ResourceWarning
============================= test session starts =============================
[...]
========== 1 failed, 39 passed, 6 skipped, 2 xpassed in 6.35 seconds ==========
Exception ignored in: <socket.socket fd=2680, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_DGRAM, proto=0>
ResourceWarning: unclosed <socket.socket fd=2680, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_DGRAM, proto=0>
```
i.e. even more spurious output (the failure is platform-specific and not worth mentioning here).

After I upgraded to the latest botocore (>=1.11 is the cutoff), things are working fine. As such, I decided to just (try to) force the `travis-36` job to load that, and skip the s3-tests otherwise. I restricted the skips to the case that `PANDAS_TESTING_MODE = "deprecate"`, because otherwise, the ResourceWarnings are filtered out anyway.

So, the last run had no warnings anymore (failure was again only #23726), but I realized that the reason for this is that now the `s3_resource` is just skipping through some more restrictive authentication checks in the newer boto (#23754).

I'm trying to cover more boto by adding it to the `travis-37` job (which is also around 10min faster than the others). Moto is supporting 3.7. starting with `1.3.7` (the latest version), but that isn't reflected in the requirements yet: spulec/moto#1886. Therefore, I'm installing through pip (after failing through conda).

OK, good news is that the ResourceWarnings are gone from the `travis-36` job (https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/456410643), which, I guess is a nice and closed-off extent for this PR.

The errors now in the `travis-37` job due to #23754 will still need to be solved, but I guess that's something for a follow-up.

@jreback
I responded to your feedback couple days ago, PTAL
@TomAugspurger Would you mind opining on https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23731#discussion_r235544075? :)

@TomAugspurger Thanks!

@jreback Should you agree as well, don't merge quite yet - I still need to set up boto to be tested in another CI job (as explained in the comment above). Will wait for your input here
What do you mean by "another" CI job? Can we take an existing one and pin moto, boto, and botocore to known versions?
That's of course what I meant... Sorry for the confusing choice of words.

@TomAugspurger 
> From what I understand there's a conflict between the latest boto/botocore and moto
#23754

Yes, there seems to be an error with the newer moto that will hopefully be fixed soon.

> We could also try to fix this at the PANDAS_TESTING_MODE level. That adds a `warnings.simplefilter` at the start of the test. Perhaps the fixture could add an ignore to our filters? Though maybe @h-vetinari already tried that.

The warning unfortunately cannot be caught by `warnings.simplefilter` (or anything else I could try, see https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/23731#issuecomment-439522832), because AFAICT, it is emitted from a finally/teardown state, where the usual mechanics don't apply anymore.

@jreback
> botocore is only a test dep, so i don't mind switching it to a higher version. Then simply add this to other builds until we are actually testing this.

It's actually an indirect (optional) dependency through `boto3`, which directly depends on it (in version lockstep: `boto3 1.x.yy <-> botocore 1.[x+3].yy`).

I added the newer moto to to the `travis-37` job, where those boto tests should now produce errors (after re-verifying that, I'll then add a specific `except` to the fixture-teardown). I'll also add `PANDAS_TESTING_MODE="deprecate"` to make sure these `boto`-tests are tested for warnings (once moto is fixed upstream).

On the other hand, I'm forcing `botocore<1.11` on the `travis-36` job (and removing `PANDAS_TESTING_MODE="deprecate"`), to make sure boto is tested until #23754 is solved.

EDIT: clarification about shifting `PANDAS_TESTING_MODE="deprecate"`
can you rebase
Failure in azure is unrelated.

I had closed this to avoid being merged, as I saw that there were some things that still need ironing out (but had no time to comment at work).
I'll split off the part that deals with the `s3_resource` fixture in a separate PR and leave the CI stuff here.

OK, so I split off #24073 which handles the `s3_resource` fixture part, but I actually realised that getting rid of the warning while still testing boto is impossible until #23754 is solved. 
Any CI job using `botocore<1.11` will have a ResourceWarning, and any job having `botocore>=1.11` will fail (or rather, silently skip the boto tests).

I would suggest to merge this nevertheless, as this was several hours worth of investigation and will help solve the problem further down the line. At the very least, this PR should remain open.
Merged master to see if https://dev.azure.com/pandas-dev/pandas/_build/results?buildId=4665 is fixed.
@TomAugspurger The failed build you linked was due to linting...? Did you mean the moto/boto failure?

I meant the linting one, it was before I started investigating.

Do you have a recommendation on the moto / boto failures? Do your changes here solve all the issues we're seeing on master? I'm still trying to piece it all together.

I have no idea about the failure in https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/463373613

The plotting / pickle failures from https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/463373616 are fixed on master now.
The ssl issue showed up in https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/463484629, so it's not just a one off. Taking a look...

Well, the failure does involve `TestPandasContainer`, which only appears in `tests/io/json/test_pandas.py`, which was touched by my recent #24073. One way to test if that is responsible for the errors is just to skip that test.

I cannot grok the test error though. It seems to fail within `pytest` itself (as `execnet` is part of that https://github.com/pytest-dev/execnet).
Nevermind, I just saw on closer look that this fails in `test_default_handler_raises`.

Truth be told, I'm not sure this PR would help with the current failures. It doesn't fundamentally change the handling of the boto errors (it just narrows down which kinds of exceptions are caught), and even more so, the failure in (e.g. https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/463496968) is in the `pytest.importorskip('boto.plugin')` itself... (which is itself a band-aid, sheesh...)

@TomAugspurger 
One error in https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/463508130 is:
```execnet.gateway_base.DumpError: can't serialize <class 'ssl.SSLSocket'>```
This might be ever so vaguely related: pytest-dev/pytest-xdist#364

Could be that pytest stumbles over something it cant serialize?

Other observations from the 3 failed CI jobs here:
* `travis-37` uses `moto 1.3.7` and crashes completely, see https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/463508130. Note that this PR added boto coverage to this job.
* `travis-27` uses `moto 1.3.4` and errors once(!) on `moto = pytest.importorskip('moto')` (which then tries to import `boto.plugin`, I think), see https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/463508132
* `travis-36` uses `moto 1.3.6` and errors 21 times, mainly(?) on `moto = pytest.importorskip('moto')`, see https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/463508133
My other PR introduced a merge conflict, sorry.

> My other PR introduced a merge conflict, sorry.

Completely normal part of developing. ;-)
Failure is (thankfully!) just a flaky hypothesis test. Could someone restart please? (@TomAugspurger? @gfyoung?)

**DO NOT MERGE**

Nevermind, I don't think the tests are actually being run at the moment, due to the *other* moto error about importing `boto.plugin`.  Argggggh....
